Divide the base shape into two regions using a vertical line at X=0.5 units. 5. Create a circle in the left region, centered at (0.0893, 0.4106) with a radius of 0.0893 units. 6. Create a smaller circle inside the previously created circle, centered at the same point with a radius of 0.0179 units. Creating loops and faces 7. Form loops for each region: - Loop 1: Includes the outer circle, vertical line, and a portion of the base shape. - Loop 2: Includes the inner circle, the remaining portion of the base shape, and the vertical line. 8. Create faces for each loop. Creating the 2D sketch for the cylindrical hole 9. Begin a new 2D sketch on the XZ plane, rotated -90 degrees around the Y-axis from the previous sketch. 10. Draw the cross-section of the cylindrical hole: - Arc 1: Start Point (0.0007, 0.4218), Mid Point (0.0893, 0.4999), End Point (0.1778, 0.4218) - Line 1: Start Point (0.1778, 0.4218), End Point (0.1424, 0.7031) - Arc 2: Start Point (0.1424, 0.7031), Mid Point (0.0893, 0.6429), End Point (0.0361, 0.7031) - Line 2: Start Point (0.0361, 0.7031), End Point (0.0007, 0.4218) 11. Add circular features: - Circle 1: Center (0.0691, 0.616), Radius 0.0089 units 12. Form loops based on the curves drawn. Scaling and transforming the 2D sketch into 3D 13. Scale the 2D sketch using the scaling factor 0.75. 14. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into 3D using the coordinate system's euler angles and translation vector. Extruding the 3D model 15. Extrude the 2D sketch to generate the 3D model with the following properties: - Extrude depth towards normal: 0.0171 units - Extrude depth opposite normal: 0 units Congratulations! The first parametric CAD part of the rectangular prism with a cylindrical hole is complete. Follow the same procedure for creating other parts if applicable.</description>
